definitions: take money or possessions from someone by deceiving or overcharging them dishonestly
examples: The dishonest mechanic tried to rook customers with unnecessary repairs
Don't let that salesman rook you into buying expensive extras

definitions: settle down to sleep or rest in a high place like birds do at night
examples: The chickens roost in the barn every evening at sunset
Pigeons roost on the building ledges throughout the downtown area

definitions: rub a hard sticky substance on something to increase friction or improve grip
examples: The violinist will rosin her bow before the concert performance
Baseball pitchers often rosin their hands for better ball control

definitions: break down and decay through natural processes caused by bacteria or fungi
gradually deteriorate or decline in quality condition or value over time
examples: The fallen apples will rot on the ground if not collected
Wood can rot when exposed to moisture for extended periods
His skills began to rot after years without practice or training
Unused machinery will rot away in the abandoned factory building

definitions: move or cause to move in a circle around a central point or axis
arrange things or people to take turns in a regular repeating pattern
examples: The Earth rotates on its axis once every twenty-four hours
Slowly rotate the handle clockwise to open the valve mechanism
Farmers rotate crops each season to maintain healthy soil conditions
The nurses rotate weekend shifts so everyone gets time off

definitions: put red coloring on the cheeks or lips to add color and enhance appearance
examples: She decided to rouge her cheeks before the photo shoot
Actors rouge their faces heavily for stage performances under lights

definitions: cause someone to wake up from sleep or become alert and active
excite or provoke someone to take action or feel strong emotions
examples: The loud alarm clock will rouse you at six tomorrow morning
It's difficult to rouse teenagers on weekend mornings for chores
The coach's speech helped rouse the team's fighting spirit completely
The unfair decision will rouse public anger against the government

definitions: defeat an enemy or opponent completely causing them to retreat in disorder
examples: The home team managed to rout their rivals forty to seven
The general's strategy helped rout the invading forces within days

definitions: travel from place to place without a fixed destination or clear purpose
examples: The photographer loves to rove through countryside villages taking pictures
Wild horses rove across the open plains searching for fresh grass

definitions: crane one's neck to stare or gawk at something with obvious curiosity
examples: Drivers often rubber at accident scenes causing more traffic delays
Tourists rubber at the tall buildings when visiting the big city

definitions: criticize or dismiss something as worthless nonsense or completely without value
examples: Critics tend to rubbish any movie that becomes too popular
Don't rubbish her ideas before giving them proper consideration first

definitions: arrange or classify something according to specific categories rules or headings
examples: Teachers rubric student essays using detailed grading criteria and standards
The library will rubric new books according to subject and genre

definitions: make fabric bunch up or form wrinkles creases or uneven folds
examples: Your shirt will ruck up if you tuck it carelessly
The carpet tends to ruck when furniture is moved across it

definitions: feel sad regret or remorse about something that happened or was done
examples: You will rue the day you decided to quit school early
She came to rue her hasty decision to sell the house

definitions: play a trump card when unable to follow suit in card games
examples: He decided to ruff with a low trump to win the trick
You can ruff when you're out of the suit being played

definitions: perform a ballroom dance with Cuban origin using hip movements and quick steps
examples: The couple learned to rumba for their wedding reception dance
Dance instructors teach students to rumba with proper rhythm and style

definitions: make a continuous deep rolling sound like distant thunder or machinery
engage in a gang fight or street brawl between rival groups
examples: Thunder began to rumble in the distance warning of approaching storms
The old truck's engine would rumble loudly when starting up cold
The two gangs planned to rumble in the vacant lot tonight
Rival schools used to rumble over territory in the old days

definitions: tell or spread stories or reports about someone that may not be true
examples: People rumour that the company plans to close the factory soon
Students rumour about which teachers might retire this school year

definitions: break or burst suddenly especially when under pressure from inside
severely damage or destroy a relationship connection or peaceful situation
examples: The water pipe could rupture if the pressure gets too high
Heavy lifting can rupture a disc in your lower back area
The scandal threatened to rupture diplomatic relations between the countries
His betrayal would rupture their twenty-year friendship beyond any repair

definitions: become covered with reddish-brown coating when iron or steel meets moisture and oxygen
examples: Metal tools will rust if left outside in rain and weather
The old car began to rust around the wheel wells first

definitions: create deep tracks or grooves in soft ground through repeated passage
examples: Heavy trucks rut the dirt road during the rainy spring season
Wagon wheels would rut the prairie trails in pioneer days long ago

definitions: cut or strike with a heavy cavalry sword that has a curved blade
examples: The cavalry officer would saber enemy soldiers during mounted charges
Pirates in old movies saber their opponents in dramatic sword fights

definitions: deliberately destroy damage or obstruct something especially for political or military advantage
examples: Enemy agents tried to sabotage the factory producing military equipment
Someone attempted to sabotage the project by deleting important files

definitions: cut or strike with a heavy cavalry sword that has a curved blade
examples: The fencer learned to sabre opponents using proper Olympic style techniques
Mounted soldiers would sabre infantry troops during nineteenth century battles

definitions: place a leather seat on a horse's back for riding
give someone an unpleasant responsibility task or financial burden
examples: The cowboy will saddle his horse before the morning cattle drive
Ranch hands saddle dozens of horses for the tourist trail rides
Don't saddle me with your debts when you leave town suddenly
The new manager was saddled with fixing all the previous mistakes

definitions: protect something or someone from harm damage or loss using preventive measures
examples: New laws safeguard children from dangerous products and harmful content online
Banks safeguard customer data using advanced encryption and security systems

definitions: sink bend or hang down in the middle from weight or pressure
become weaker or less active showing decline in energy or performance
examples: The old mattress began to sag in the middle after years
Heavy snow can make roof structures sag dangerously without proper support
Sales tend to sag during the slow summer months every year
His energy would sag in the late afternoon before dinner time

definitions: raise hand to forehead as formal military sign of respect
show respect or honor someone through gesture acknowledgment or tribute
examples: Soldiers must salute when officers enter the room or pass by
The sailor will salute the flag during the morning ceremony
We salute the brave firefighters who risk their lives saving others
The crowd rose to salute the championship team with loud applause

definitions: rescue or save something from loss destruction or waste to use again
examples: Divers work to salvage cargo from the sunken ship's hull remains
We managed to salvage some furniture from the house before demolition

definitions: apply healing ointment or do something to ease guilt conscience or wounded feelings
examples: The nurse will salve the burn with medicated cream three times daily
He tried to salve his conscience by donating to charity anonymously

definitions: perform a lively Brazilian dance with rhythmic steps and swaying hip movements
examples: The dancers samba through the streets during Rio's colorful carnival celebration
Dance students learn to samba with authentic Brazilian rhythm and energy

definitions: rub wood or other surfaces with rough paper to make them smooth
examples: You need to sandpaper the wooden table before applying fresh paint
Carefully sandpaper the rough edges to avoid getting painful splinters later

definitions: gradually weaken or drain someone's energy strength or confidence over time
examples: Long hours of overtime work will sap your energy and motivation
Constant criticism can sap a child's confidence and self-esteem completely

definitions: use humor irony or exaggeration to criticize and expose people's faults
examples: The comedian loves to satirize politicians and their empty campaign promises
Many writers satirize social media culture in their contemporary novels today

definitions: soak something thoroughly so it cannot absorb any more liquid
fill something completely to the point where no more can be added
examples: Heavy rain will saturate the soil making the ground extremely muddy
You should saturate the sponge before cleaning the dirty kitchen counters
Advertisements saturate television during major sporting events and prime time
The market became saturated with similar products from competing companies

definitions: attack someone or something fiercely and violently causing severe injury
examples: The guard dog might savage intruders who enter the property uninvited
Critics savage the new movie calling it the worst film ever

definitions: know understand or comprehend something with practical intelligence and good judgment
examples: Experienced investors savvy market trends better than beginners do every time
You need to savvy local customs when traveling to foreign countries

definitions: cut wood or other material using a tool with sharp metal teeth
examples: The carpenter will saw the boards to the correct length today
You can saw through metal pipes using the right blade type

definitions: form a dry protective crust over a healing wound or sore
work in place of striking workers breaking union solidarity
examples: Small cuts usually scab over within a few days of injury
Don't pick at wounds that scab or they won't heal properly
Some workers chose to scab during the strike for extra money
Union members refuse to scab even when facing financial hardship

definitions: construct temporary wooden or metal framework to support workers and materials
examples: Construction crews scaffold the building exterior before starting renovation work
Workers carefully scaffold around the statue for restoration and cleaning

definitions: cut or shape the edge of something with curved indentations
examples: The baker will scallop the pie crust edges for decoration
Seamstresses often scallop the hem of fancy dresses and curtains

definitions: buy and resell tickets or goods quickly for higher profit
cut someone's hair extremely short close to the skin
examples: People illegally scalp concert tickets outside the venue for profit
Some traders scalp stocks making small profits on quick trades
The barber will scalp your head if you request a buzz cut
Military recruits get their heads scalped on the first day

definitions: trick or deceive someone to get their money through dishonest schemes
examples: Con artists scam elderly people with fake charity donation requests online
Don't let anyone scam you with promises of easy money schemes

definitions: do work carelessly or incompletely to save time money or effort
examples: Lazy workers scamp their duties leaving tasks only partially finished
Don't scamp the paint job or it will look terrible later

definitions: provide barely enough of something or limit the supply grudgingly
examples: The recipe says to scant the sugar for a less sweet taste
Don't scant the butter or the cookies will be too dry

definitions: leave a permanent mark on skin or surface from injury or damage
examples: Deep cuts will scar if they don't heal properly with care
The accident would scar his face despite multiple reconstructive surgeries later

definitions: eat food quickly and greedily often in large amounts
join two pieces of wood or metal by cutting matching notches
examples: Hungry teenagers scarf down pizza after school sports practice every day
Don't scarf your food so fast or you'll get indigestion
Carpenters scarf wooden beams together for stronger structural support in buildings
You can scarf metal pipes using special welding techniques and tools

definitions: go away quickly often used as a command to animals
examples: The cat will scat when you spray it with water bottle
Scat before I call the police about your loud music tonight

definitions: search for and collect usable items from waste or things others discarded
examples: Homeless people scavenge through dumpsters looking for food and clothing
Artists scavenge scrap metal to create unique sculptures and installations
